AbstractText: Stubblefield and associates in focusing on the use of laminaria tents with intra-amniotic prostaglandin F2alpha (PGF2alpha) indicated that cultures were taken before and after insertion, but they failed to designate the organisms isolated or the percentage of positive cultures for pathogens before and after the insertion of the laminaria. Both philosophically and practically treatment begins at the time of laminaria insertion which, by the authors' admission, has a lag period of 14-19 hours prior to drug administration. In the present program the patient was admitted overnight, indicating at least a 2 day hospital stay. In addition, insertion of a laminaria tent for a period this long might initiate an ongoing infective process. There is no question that insertion of the tents is in itself an abortifacient maneuver, meaning that cumulative abortion rate rigures--such as those which appear in the article--are misleading. Preparation of the figure to show the time span from insertion of the laminaria to abortion would clarify this point.

GeneralNote: TJ: AMERICAN JOURNAL OF OBSTETRICS AND GYNECOLOGY.

Journal.Title: American journal of obstetrics and gynecology

Article.ArticleTitle: Letter: Use of laminaria tents with prostaglandin.
